explanation: The formal process of registering at a university. You submit documents, pay the semester fee, and get your student ID.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Schools don't teach this. Continuing-gen students hear about it from siblings or parents.

explanation: Officially leaving the university, either by graduating, by choice, or because of academic failure.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The word itself is intimidating and rarely explained before it matters.

explanation: Paying your semester fee to confirm you will continue studying next semester. Miss the deadline and you get automatically de-enrolled.
why_first_gen_dont_know: No one warns you about this. Continuing-gen students' parents remind them.

explanation: A fee (usually 100-400 EUR) paid every semester. NOT tuition. It covers the student union, transit ticket, and student services.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Easily confused with tuition fees. Many first-gen students panic thinking university costs thousands.

explanation: Points measuring study workload. 1 ECTS = roughly 30 hours of work. A full semester is 30 ECTS, a bachelor is 180 ECTS.
why_first_gen_dont_know: No school equivalent exists. Parents who studied explain the system.

explanation: A thematic unit of study consisting of one or more courses (lectures, seminars) that belong together and end with one exam.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The modular structure of university is completely different from school.

explanation: A professor talks, you listen and take notes. Usually 60-90 minutes. Hundreds of students. No interaction expected.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Very different from school classes. The passive format can feel alienating without context.

explanation: A smaller class (15-30 students) where you discuss topics, present, and actively participate. More interactive than lectures.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The expectation to speak up can be intimidating when you don't know the norms.

explanation: A practice session led by an advanced student (not a professor) where you work through exercises and ask questions.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Having a peer teach you is unfamiliar. Many first-gen students skip these, not knowing they're the most helpful sessions.

explanation: A written academic paper (10-25 pages) on a topic from your seminar. Usually your main grade for that module.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Academic writing conventions are never taught in school. Continuing-gen students get guidance from parents.

explanation: A timed written exam at the end of the semester. Usually 60-120 minutes. Covers all lecture content.
why_first_gen_dont_know: University exams cover much more material than school exams. The self-study expectation is new.

explanation: The expected time to complete your degree (6 semesters for bachelor, 4 for master). Going over is common and okay.
why_first_gen_dont_know: First-gen students often panic about exceeding it. It affects BAföG but is not a hard deadline.

explanation: A semester off where you stay enrolled but don't take courses. Used for internships, illness, or personal reasons.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The option exists but is never advertised. Continuing-gen students learn about it from family.

explanation: The official rules for exams in your degree program: how many attempts, deadlines, pass requirements.
why_first_gen_dont_know: A dense legal document that nobody reads proactively. Critical for understanding your rights.

explanation: Lists all modules in your degree: content, ECTS, exam type, prerequisites. Your roadmap for the entire degree.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The existence of this document is assumed knowledge.

explanation: The grade cutoff for admission to popular degree programs. If your Abitur grade is below the NC, you don't get in.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The NC system is complex (main procedure, coordination, waiting semesters) and poorly explained.

explanation: Semesters after your Abitur where you are NOT enrolled at any university. Used to improve your chances for NC-restricted programs.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The strategic use of waiting semesters is passed down in academic families.

explanation: The elected student representatives for your specific department. They organize events, help with problems, and advocate for students.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Many first-gen students don't know these exist, let alone that they can help.

explanation: The overall student government of your university. They run services like legal advice, housing help, and the semester ticket.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The services AStA provides are exactly what first-gen students need but don't know about.

explanation: The elected body that makes decisions about student affairs and the semester fee allocation.
why_first_gen_dont_know: University democracy is a foreign concept if your family has no academic background.

explanation: The formal German word for your classmates at university. Used in official contexts.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The word itself can feel exclusionary if you've never heard it before arriving.

explanation: The head of a faculty (department). A professor who also handles administrative leadership.
why_first_gen_dont_know: University hierarchy is opaque to outsiders.

explanation: A paid position where students work for a professor or department. Great for CV and networking.
why_first_gen_dont_know: These positions are often filled through personal networks. First-gen students don't know they exist.

explanation: Fixed times when you can meet your professor one-on-one for questions, advice, or paper discussions.
why_first_gen_dont_know: No school equivalent. Many first-gen students don't know office hours are free personal consulting.

explanation: The subsidized canteen on campus. Meals cost 2-5 EUR. Cheapest lunch option for students.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The word is Latin and not self-explanatory. The subsidized pricing is not widely known.

explanation: Your unique number at the university. Needed for exams, library, email, and all administrative processes.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Where to find it and when you need it is assumed knowledge.

explanation: The list of all courses offered in a semester. You use this to build your own schedule.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Building your own schedule is radically different from school. No one does it for you.

explanation: Some universities allow a 'free first attempt' at an exam: if you fail, it doesn't count as an official attempt.
why_first_gen_dont_know: A hidden advantage that only insiders know about. Check your Prüfungsordnung.

explanation: Usually your last chance to pass an exam. Failing means de-enrollment from that program (not from the university).
why_first_gen_dont_know: The consequences are severe but poorly communicated. First-gen students often don't know until it's too late.

explanation: Government financial support for students. Half grant (free), half interest-free loan. Based on parents' income.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Many families don't know it exists, don't understand the application, or assume they won't qualify.

explanation: The central platform for applying to NC-restricted programs in Germany. Used for medicine, pharmacy, law, etc.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Whether to apply via Hochschulstart or directly at the university is confusing without guidance.

explanation: Official document listing all courses you've completed, with grades and ECTS. Needed for master applications.
why_first_gen_dont_know: When to request it, who issues it, and what it contains are all assumed knowledge.

explanation: Research-based degree after your master, supervised by a professor. Takes 3-5 years. Results in a Dr. title.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The entire concept of academic careers beyond the master is foreign to non-academic families.

explanation: Post-doctoral qualification required to become a full professor in Germany. An additional academic 'super-thesis'.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Only relevant for academic careers, but first-gen students who want to stay in academia need to know early.

explanation: A part-time job (max 20h/week during semester) with student tax benefits. Great for CV and income.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The legal framework (20h rule, tax benefits, BAföG interaction) is complex and poorly explained.

explanation: A mandatory semester-long internship in some degree programs (especially at FHs). Part of your curriculum.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Finding and securing an internship requires networks that first-gen students often lack.

explanation: The certificate proving you're allowed to study. Usually the Abitur, but also possible via vocational qualification.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Many don't know that you can study WITHOUT Abitur if you have professional experience.

explanation: Free counseling offered by every university. Helps with study choice, problems, and career planning.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The service exists at every university but first-gen students often don't know about it or feel it's 'not for them'.

explanation: University classes starting at 'c.t.' (cum tempore) begin 15 minutes after the listed time. 10:00 c.t. means 10:15.
why_first_gen_dont_know: A purely academic convention that confuses everyone on their first day. Insider knowledge.

explanation: A research paper (30-60 pages) written in your final semester. You choose a topic with a supervising professor.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The entire process (finding a supervisor, choosing a topic, academic writing norms) is unfamiliar.

explanation: Your student ID often doubles as your library card. Gives access to books, databases, and study rooms.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Academic libraries work differently from public libraries. The resources available are not obvious.

explanation: University VPN gives you access to academic databases, journals, and e-books from home. Free for students.
why_first_gen_dont_know: The existence of free access to millions of research papers is not communicated proactively.

explanation: Using someone else's text or ideas without citing them. Treated very seriously in academia — can lead to expulsion.
why_first_gen_dont_know: Academic citation norms are not taught in school. The consequences are severe and poorly explained.
